segments.text: And the length of these tours is brought about by the human element of our society, the softness in which we live.
Okay.
Okay.
I want to talk about another issue as far as the man is concerned, and you've already mentioned this.
I'd like your comment on it, maybe a change from your first tour to your—

when you return in your command and that is by 1970 and the early 1970s in the press there were a number of stories about drugs, about enlisted men who didn't want to fight and who wouldn't follow the officers and about fragging.
Maybe these things were blown up.
I don't know.
I'd like your opinion.
Do you have examples?
I read a lot about that before I went back on my second tour in August of 1971.
I read a lot about it.
And we had three or more divisions left over there.

When I was asked to come back by General Abrams because of some failures at the DMZ and also Firebase Barry Ann down in the Miracle Division and some failures on the Cambodian border which caused the relief of a general officer that I later replaced, I found no fragging incidences.
I did send one battery of artillery people home because I found them on marijuana one day and they weren't able to fire their weapons on the DMZ, so I just deactivated that unit.
What happened to those soldiers?
They shipped them home.
What kind of discharge is it?
I don't have any idea.
I don't have any idea.
Did they ship them home and discharge them?
I don't have any idea what happened to them.
Who was in charge?
I warned them out of the theater.
Who was in charge?
There was a captain.
What happened to him?
I have no idea what happened to him.
Did he go back, too?
They all went back to the States.
They were scheduled for deactivation within a month or two months anyway to go back home, and when I found them totally ineffective because of the drug, I just said, out, and that's what happened.
I found no fragging instances.
I can tell you this, that all sort of things happen to soldiers and to civilians if they're in a place in which they're dissatisfied and they're not properly occupied.
and no one is providing them adventure or a challenge, they'll go make it for themselves.

And when they're in an area outside of their own habitat of the United States, in a foreign country, as far as they're concerned, nobody can see them, and you can't tell what the hell they're liable to come up with.
And that's exactly what has happened.
The policy of the United States was conduct the war, don't kill any enemy, and don't get killed yourself.
So what does a general or a colonel do under that sort of situation?
He sits on his hands.
And one with a burning desire to succeed,

and understand all these problems and been through them before, he will create an ingenious way in leadership of keeping these men occupied and doing something in order to provide them some adventure and challenge.
And I want to tell you that it isn't an easy task at all.
Those elements wasn't provided to these men.
They had nothing to do in a foreign country.
And we're going to get into something.
And that's what happens many times.
It's not the first time it's happened, but I never saw it rampant at all.
In Vietnam?
In Vietnam, yes.
Never.
And a good comparison was that the first division in the 15 months I was with it won AWOL.
People were doing something 24 hours a day.
When I came back, that was in 1966 and 67.
I came back in 71 and 72, and apparently, as a matter of fact, I was back there too.
more or less, corral all of these evil things that was going on and sort them out and get people sorted out.
And I found just what I've explained, the high command from the presidential
the Congress, Department of Defense, and the State Department conduct that war, don't get anybody killed, and don't kill any enemy.
And by God, what in the hell kind of war is that and what do you do?
And the soldier says, why in the hell am I over here?
And I agree with the soldier.
Did you have men come up to you, or enlisted, or officers, and say, General, why am I here?
I never had one ask me.
He didn't have to because I told him why he was there.

I told him he was there because our government wanted us here in order to, because it felt that way, and we're going to support the government, and we're going to do it the best we could, and whether you liked it or not, that was beside the damn point.
And they never asked me, but in my heart I knew that they, uh, you want to let us fight, is what I'm for.
And we were sending them home pretty fast then anyway.
Yeah, right.
I was wondering about another issue, which was some controversy.
Of course, we lost the war and
Some people say, well, we didn't use the right strategy.
And then they say, Westmoreland strategy, well, one part of the strategy was search and destroy.
Using that tactic to go out in the field and search and destroy the enemy.
And then, of course, there was the accountability.
How do you measure progress in a war like this?
And one measure was the body count.
And that's come under a lot of criticism.
First, what do you think about search and destroy?
Search and destroy in a very inefficient way and a very costly way of conducting a war against insurgency.
Sir Robert Thompson, advisor to President Nixon, and I totally agree that to stop insurgency from one country to the other, you go after the base, the base of the insurgency.
You go after North Vietnam and totally destroy it, eliminate it.
You don't need any search and destroy.
We also agree that we destroyed, and I had a major hand in this, in destroying the offensive capability of General Giep.
At the time of victory for the United States, our home base collapsed.
The United States collapsed and wiped away victory.
Our Congress, our president, our government, our administration, our people collapsed.
at the time of victory.
Sir Robert Thompson could see that very clearly.
Their base never collapsed.
Their base was never attacked.
They never came to a peace term until they got 11 days of B-52s day and night in November and December of 1972.
Then they went to the peace table.
which should give the world an indication of how you fight insurgency.
I wanted to blow the dams and drown about two million of them plus all their rice fields and starve them out.
It's war.
Never happened.
Johnson came over and apparently talked to Westmoreland about
What do you need to go north?
And Westmoreland wanted another quarter of a million men, so Johnson goes back and McNamara and the rest of them throw her a laird, I guess, throw up their hands.
They just can't do that.
We didn't need another quarter of a million men.
We needed B-52s 24 hours around the clock, and every tactical fighter bomber that we had in the business

24 hours a day around the clock and after we had bombed them to shreds for about 30 to 60 days land the 82nd airborne and 101st air mobile or the first big red one air mobile over there and it was all over with did we do that no the great affluency here and the
and the leftist elements in this country denied a frightened administration of Congress to face these problems with common sense and sound judgment.
That's what it's all about.
The American people did it to themselves.
The soldiers, the sailors and the airmen,
were really and truly the finest I have ever seen in anybody's Army, Navy, or Air Force or Marine Corps anywhere in the world.
They were absolutely phenomenal.
And I just can't say too much for them.
They never lost a battle, as far as I'm concerned.
I can't think of one that they ever lost.
And they were in some tough ones and in a war which is best described by not a front line anywhere, but the war was 360 degrees.
In front of you, behind you, all around you.
Whether you were an individual or a division or a battalion or a company or what it is, the war was all around you.
Now that is peculiar and unusual to our way of warfare in this country or any other country in the world.
It's always been before all the good guys on one side of the line and all the bad guys on the other side.
And you shoot at each other back and forth.
That's not the way it was in this war in Vietnam and counterinsurgency.
This was a very demanding thing that required not looking in one direction but totally all the way around.
That is another thing that contributed to the hardship on the soldier and the officer.
What kind of strategy do you think that we should have had to fight this type of 360-degree war?
Go after the base.
Go after the base, North Vietnam.
Don't deploy any divisions in South Vietnam.
Go take the base out.
Take it all out.
All the support out.
Take out the sanctuaries.
Can you imagine me having instructions issued that if I'm fired on from Cambodia, I cannot return the fire?
And I said, you go to hell.
And I was standing with General Prilliman on the Cambodian border in Tainan Province in a small stream, maybe 20 meters, that ran down between Cambodia and Tainan Province.
And General Prilliman, Lieutenant Colonel then, who commanded 2nd Infantry, was moving along.
found a lot of supply bases just inside Cambodia, many more on the other side, policy where we weren't allowed to fire over there.
And I was standing talking to him when the small arms fire broke out, killed his radio operator, and wounded another man there near us.
And I said, Dick,
Let's get some artillery fire on these bastards.
He said, sir, we're not permitted to fire over there.
I grabbed the radio from the dead soldier and called artillery fire on them over there until I felt that I'd killed every one of them.
And it wasn't 24 hours until it came from the President of the United States
back to McVie, who has violated the no firing into Cambodia.
Prince Suenok had reported to the President of the United States, the United States State Department, that they had been fired on.
Well, the First Division was operating out there.
Division Commander General Depew got called to find out who it was that was firing.
First Division was the only one in Tainan Province operating on the Cambodian border.
He didn't know what they wanted, so he went back and about.
He called me and he said,
You were in charge of all the maneuver and fire and everything?
I said, yeah, that's right, sir.
He said, apparently one of our units had fired into Cambodia.
I said, well, what's the circumstances?
He said, well, political authorities in Phnom Penh has relayed
to the United States and the President has asked Comments McVie to give him a report on this and find out who it is that violated the policy.
The outcome of this was, I said, I fired into Cambodia.
I said, I was standing with Dick Preliman,
yesterday afternoon talking to him when the fire came in and killed his radio operator and wounded another man.
And the fire continued to come in.
And I said, uh, I asked Dick to get some fire going back and he said the policy was that, uh, which I knew was that, uh, uh,
He couldn't fire over there.
I did this because it was his command.
It was his battalion.
And I wanted him to run his battalion, but he couldn't do that because he was following the policy.
So I took the radio, adjusted the artillery there.
And I want to say this, that I'm ready to call a national press and make it known to the world

that I do not intend to have a United States soldier wounded or killed by enemy fire from Cambodia and me not fire back and if they want to send another boy out here in my place go right ahead but I'll be damned if I'm gonna
Allow American soldiers to be shot, wounded, and killed from fire from some sanctuary, and me, allow them to get by with that.
I'll put that blood on somebody else's hands, not my own.
What did the general say?
He went back to Colonel McVeigh.
Did he agree with you?
He agreed.
He always agreed.
He's a hell of a, most of the time, I guess, he's a hell of a great guy, smart as hell.
He understand clearly he'd been in combat during World War II.
He knew what it was all about.
He knew people.
And lo and behold, the policy changed the next day.
Do not pursue, but return fire if you're shot at.
That's what I did.
Policy was changed.
So that's the sort of stuff he put up.

crap you got to put up with all political all gimmickry bureaucratic gimmickry politically all political stuff here in a democracy that's what you have to live with what'd you think of westmoreland well west a uh um
ran for governor after he retired, so he must have some political aspirations.
He treated me well while I was over there.
He respected the fact that I was a combat leader, and that's all you have to do, and I guess that's all you can ask for.
so you can discount any other things that you might hear or see or do.
As long as the top guy respects you for what you are and is a combat leader, then you've made the grade, you see.
So I have no comment to make about him at all, except that he did run for governor back here,
Maybe he had some political ambitions all along.

As a matter of fact, how can you be a four-star general and dealing with an ambassador every day and dealing with a president of a foreign country every day and at the same time be a combat leader every day?
So I got no criticism of Westy at all.
How well did you know him?
Well, he used to visit with me almost every other day or so.

And he'd come out when he was going to call off somebody of higher authority between the division, say the corps commander or the field force commander, but had already convinced Westy that he ought to change the course of action or he ought to stop this operation and go do something else and so forth.
He's come out and visited me and reversed the corps commander.
So he took your opinion?
Absolutely.
And that happened many times.
Will you compare him with Abrams who took over in 1968?
Well, you'd have to say General Westmoreland was a boy scout and General Abrams was a combat fighting soldier.
Well tell me more.
Well that's about it.
Experience-wise, there's no comparison.
General Abrams had, as I said earlier, been a very successful tank leader during World War II.
As I mentioned, there were two of us, Abrams and myself.
He'd been very successful.
He'd been very successful at peacetime as a commander, and he commanded combat command in the armored division and commanded the division.
And he was a tough guy, smart, got things done, highly respected.
And the two people are just totally different personalities.
As I say, one was a boy scout, immaculate, everything just perfect and so on and forth.
That's not a good, rough, tough, brawling type commander that gets in and faces a cold steel battle, you see.
Westie had never had that kind of experience.
Abrams had.
How'd you get along with Abrams?
I guess he, best compliment he ever paid me, I was in the hospital when I'd lost his eye.
When he said, he said, I want you to get out of here, I'm going to give you a,
another command, and I said, well... And he said you were going to Korea.

He said, you're going to Korea, and I said, well, I don't know whether I'll have a one eye or not, and he said, you son of a bitch, I'd rather have you with one eye, and most of these bastards were three.
I loved him.
We've been very close all of our lives.
We had a battalion commander to tell you about, Abe.
We had a battalion commander, and he had a battalion commander in the 4th Army Division named Pat Hyde.
Pat was a diabetic, and he stole his way overseas during World War II.
He had a class of 40 at West Point.
And Pat was doing well over there and was a battalion commander and his wife would send him insulin in a cake and stuff, you know.
Every week they'd send him a cake during the war and baked in the cake was insulin so nobody knew what was going on.
He didn't have to be in the war.
Well, old Pat did a hell of a job and we served together after the war.
He was in the 4th Armored Division with Abe.
I was in the 2nd, of course.
And Pat died on us after the war.
They kind of forced him out.
He died.
I was at West Point and Abe came up and stayed with me and Mrs. H in our house.
And we had a neighbor from across the street
So, this neighbor was Colonel Purdy, also a friend of Colonel Pat Hyde.
Abrams and I, he was so dedicated and so respectful of what Pat Hyde had done as a commander.

battalion commander in his unit in Fourth Armored had been doing World War II that we set up the entire night and talked about what Pat had done and what others had done and what many had failed to do.
And we, in addition to that, consumed
considerable amount of beverage and never went to sleep that night and got up the next day and took good care of Pat Hyde and putting him away.
He was a hell of a guy.
So Abram was a personable sort of fella and but officially he's a real tough fella also.
from the standpoint of standards and requiring everybody to do everything right.
Of course, I believe in that thoroughly and I think that's one of the things that created a closeness between the two of us.
Do you think that it would have made much difference in the war if Abrams would have been that first commander from 64 to 68 instead of Westmoreland?
I have no doubt that there would have been a difference.
But whether the political side of our country and the people would have allowed General Abrams to do what he knew that was necessary to win, and that was to go north and take the base,
I don't know.
I could only speculate on that.
The way he believed in air power, and the way I believe in air power, I don't need many divisions if I've got the freedom of my air power.
I think we had more than enough divisions if the politicians and the people in this country would have permitted us to use our power, our air power and our own ground power and Navy power.
We could have eliminated that conflict over there, not in eight years, but somewhere between 30 and 90 days.
Somewhere between 30 and 90 days.
And how would you have done it?
I would attack the North and bomb them into submission.
And where would you have to have?
I would then have landed safely all over the place because there wouldn't have been any resistance left.
I tore totally their military capability.
Not civilians.
but I'm talking about their military capabilities, their training bases, their units, their divisions, their organizations, their supply dumps, their ammunition dumps.
Totally destroyed them, totally eliminated them, totally eliminated the capability for them to receive anymore.
What about the fear that politicians have that maybe China or the Soviet Union will respond?
General Patton told me one time, don't ever worry about your damn flanks.
Swear for the objective.
And if you allow your flanks to interfere with you, they'll never take your objective.
And he's 100% right.
China wants to come in, just tell them I'm going to have to nuke hell out of you, baby.
So if you want to come into this, I'm going to nuke hell out of you because I don't have enough ground forces here to cover you convincingly, and you ought to know that.
So you get in it, and I'm going to nuke hell out of you.
What do you think they're going to do?
They're going to say, Jesus Christ, them son of a bitches mean business, and we better stay the hell away from them.
What about the problem that we didn't, that the Congress never, and the President too,
never considered this a war.
They always considered it a conflict, and LBJ never took a declaration of war.
I mean, you just can't invade a country without a declaration of war, can you?
Well, we were still operating under a national emergency from Korea.
That had never been called off.
So, he wasn't totally incorrect in his not declaring a national emergency, but let me tell you what happens, and I'll describe to you what happens in case you do,
want to declare a national emergency.

Stacked in the Pentagon, and I used to have responsibility for a large share of it, it must be 10 feet high of emergency legislation that the moment you declare a national emergency is submitted to the Congress, that legislation will even cut down the amount of fuel that you put in your lawnmower.
and your automobile and your lights, that legislation will stop the total progress of this country from the standpoint of doing what you want to do.
And that wasn't necessary.
And as I said, it wasn't necessary to call up the reserves either.
It wasn't that much of a problem if you had gone about it to win it and kept the politicians out of it and let the military get it over with by going after the base from which they operated.
We didn't do that.
We have got to learn

to go fight these wars and won in the Middle East without being totally disruptive to our society and our society on the other hand has got to respect this and quit and to come off of their leftist disinterest
and lackadaisical attitude about what is of national interest to the United States of America and their welfare.
And I don't know when that's going to come.
But we can't be disruptive to the United States because we're going to go over and stop Soviet from taking Saudi Arabia and Kuwait and Bahrain and Iraq
Israel.
We don't need that much, we don't need total mobilization in this country, three years of mobilization and disruptive of life here.
We need to selectively go about this.
What kind of progress you make if you take all of the reserve officers out of the school system here in the Dallas-Fort Worth area?
And all the doctors.
and many, many more.
Some of the critics have said that one of the problems with this war is that we were trying to win the hearts and minds of the people.
That was one of the policies.
In the South, yeah, we were using such massive firepower, which you've already spoken of.
We were using such massive firepower that we were too dependent on technology.
Do you think that we were too dependent on technology?
Not at all.
First place, out where the firepower was being used, there wasn't any civilians out there.
They'd been killed off and destroyed 20 years before by a communist element.
And firepower is the cheapest way to go.
You use firepower instead of expending American soldiers.
American soldiers, he's a person.
He's people.
He belongs to someone important in the United States.
He's important himself.
You don't want to expend the important part of America against the cheap part of communism.
Under communism, people are cheap.
Weapons and materialistic things are very important because they're atheist beliefs.
But in American way of life, and in my belief in Americans, is that people are important.
and that the cheap part of it, they're made by the grace of God.
Bombs and artillery pieces and firepower, that's all made by hand, and that's cheap stuff.
You can make it in the back end of anybody's garage in many instances.
So why use the important part of America, pit the important part of America against the cheap part of communism?
That is the American soldier against their soldier.
Let's pit our cheap part of America against the cheap part of communism.
Let them have the firepower.
That's the way I see it.
What did you think of the quality of the Vietnamese as far as fighters were concerned?
You mean the South Vietnamese?
Yes.
They'd been at war for twenty years and their leaders were getting tired of those that hadn't been killed.
And after you've been wounded about 10 times or more in 20 years of war, the incentive to go get killed with 11th time is not very great.
And that's a very interesting thing.
I think that might be true in the case of America also.
I hope that answered your question on that one.
good units and there were bad ones, but after twenty years, you know, you get pretty tired.
Well, the North Vietnamese had also been at war for that amount of time, yeah.
They, for the most part, were on the offensive.
Yep.
What did you think of— On the offensive, the offensive had a—the offensive

it's a sort of thing that provides adventure and challenge and there's not much adventure into being on the defensive and being kidnapped and clocked and trying to defend yourself so it's an attitudinal sort of thing and in addition to that I have to compliment the communists in their products
Now, maybe their methods of attaining it are not so— are attaining the highest spree and the dedication that the communist soldier has.
I don't—maybe not condone some of their methods or any of their methods for attaining that within an individual, but they do it better than anybody I know of.
You've got to give them credit for it.
and they make a little guy very tenacious.
But if you've got a person that's born in the hardship, raised in the hardship, trained to be a fighter in the hardship,
That has one hell of a motivation in building tenacity in the individual towards surviving.
You said earlier in this interview that you respected the German soldier even though you beat him.
Did you respect the Vietnamese enemy and General Guillem?
I respected him as a soldier, but I didn't think he was so great as everybody else thought he might be.
Because when he came down conventionally for the first time,
I destroyed him without American ground troops.
I destroyed him totally with tactical air power and Vietnamese and a handful of American advisors and American air power.
He should have been able to foresee after looking at
capability of Americans to put in firepower, or the American availability of firepower, he should have been able to made a better judgment than he did.
So, I respect him as a soldier, but he had no damn business of trying to set up his
southern governmental headquarters in my area, in my ballpark.
So he's pretty stupid as far as I'm concerned.
Now, he might have done that in somebody else's ballpark, but not mine.
Maybe he didn't respect the enemy.
I don't think he did.
He knew who I was, though.
He did?
Oh, yeah.
How do you know?
Oh, they monitor you.
When you're in the clear on the radio, they'll come up on your net, and they'll call you by your call sign, when you're in the clear on the clear net.
Did he mention you in his memoirs?
I don't remember.
No, I don't know whether he did or not.
He probably didn't want to talk about that.
If I was him, I wouldn't want to talk about that one at all.
Because he just lost his ass.
Every damn tank he had in a matter of eight or nine hours.
Most of them never even got a chance to fire one round of ammunition.
Not one round of ammunition.
Let's talk about the press.
A lot of people, we talked a little bit about this yesterday when I was leaving.
A lot of people say that the press should not have been allowed to come into Vietnam because they spectacularized the war.
that they had their own purposes.
This is the first televised war in American history, and it had a profound impact on the society, watching that every single night.
Tell me about your relations with the press.
How did you get along with them?
Do you think they were accurate in reporting over your feelings?
I think a lot depended on the individual.
